user_input: How does the Computer Science Head of Department's welcome emphasize the importance of skill development and diversity in the department, and how are the assessment periods for Computer Science modules structured to accommodate students' workloads?
response:
- The Head of Department emphasizes skill development by highlighting fundamental skills like understanding new concepts, solving problems, debugging code, and writing reports. He also mentions that these basics enable more advanced achievements such as revolutions in AI, healthcare, finance, media, learning, work, and governance.
  - Steps:
    1. Embrace the opportunities to develop your computer science skills through coursework and exams.
    2. Review the module cap policy for each module/ delivery to understand the number of places available (module cap).
- Assessment periods are structured to accommodate students' workloads by providing provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners, allowing feedback on coursework alongside provisional marks or sometimes first.
  - Steps:
    1. Check the Computer Science exam script policy and provisional marks policy in the UCL Academic Manual.
    2. Monitor Moodle forums for any delays in module feedback.
- The emphasis on diversity is reflected in the department's multidisciplinary approach, collaboration with various faculties, and commitment to inclusivity, fostering a community of great minds where students can shape their experiences and future careers.
  - Steps:
    1. Engage with peers from different backgrounds and disciplines within the UCL community.
    2. Participate in interdisciplinary projects or events that highlight diversity and inclusion.
retrieved_contexts:
One word captures the uniqueness of our department: diversity. We adopt a broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist. While we embrace fundamental theory, we also have a strong emphasis on applications and translation of theory into practical tools that impact the real world. We are highly multidisciplinary, working closely with every other UCL faculty linking to medicine and health, arts and humanities, politics and law, education, maths and life sciences. We collaborate with partners in industry, health services, and government to translate computational advances to impact. We are committed to removing barriers to achieving excellence and fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts of students and staff. The creativity and breadth of ideas this provides is key to exploiting core computer science skills effectively. These values and activities pervade the teaching we deliver to you.  
So I encourage you to embrace the opportunities of being part of this amazing place. Help shape the department and the discipline as they evolve into the future. And let them shape you as a computer scientist and a human being.  
I am excited to meet you and look forward to working with you all over the coming year.  
Prof. Daniel Alexander Head of Department  
Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.

UCL is a community of great minds. You are a valuable member of that community. I hope you will take every opportunity to shape your time with us, so that your experience is the best possible.  
Dr Michael Spence  
UCL President and Provost  
Head of Department's welcome  
Welcome to UCL's Department of Computer Science.  
Our discipline is set to produce the biggest technological advances of this century. It will have profound influence on life on Earth. It is all of you that will lead these advances. Our aim is to equip you to achieve that with skill, rigour, integrity, and a clear and complete understanding of how your work influences the world.  
It starts with the basics: understanding new concepts; solving problems; debugging code; writing reports. These are the skills that enable the sublime: revolutions in AI, healthcare, finance, media, the way we learn, work, and govern the country.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.
reference: In the Computer Science Head of Department's welcome, Prof. Daniel Alexander highlights the importance of developing fundamental skills such as understanding new concepts, solving problems, debugging code, and writing reports, which are essential for achieving technological advances in areas like AI, healthcare, and finance. He also emphasizes the department's unique focus on diversity, adopting a broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist, combining fundamental theory with practical applications, and fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts. Regarding assessments, the department carefully manages assessment dates to consider students' workloads. Assessments for Computer Science modules typically include coursework, tests, presentations, and examinations. Coursework submissions usually occur during the term in which the module is delivered plus two to three weeks. Examinations take place from 29 April to 30 May 2025, with additional late summer assessment periods and a January resit period for postgraduate taught programmes. Assessment deadlines may be set during Reading Weeks but not during closure periods, weekends, or UK bank holidays, ensuring a balanced workload for students.

user_input: How does UCL's Information Security Policy guide students in protecting their data, and what informal resolution options are recommended before submitting a formal complaint regarding data protection issues?
response: UCL’s Information Security Policy guides students to encrypt sensitive data appropriately and securely back up encryption keys. Before submitting a formal complaint about data protection issues, students should first try informal resolutions such as speaking with their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, or the Students' Union's Advice Service. Source: Data Protection (how UCL uses student information)
retrieved_contexts:
If students need to store or exchange sensitive data, then this should be appropriately encrypted. Where data is encrypted, the encryption key should be securely backed up to avoid data loss.  
Information Security | UCL  
File storage & sharing | UCL Information Services Division  
Encryption | UCL Information Security

Data protection and intellectual property  
Information on how UCL uses student information, for what purposes, and the steps taken to safeguard this information; where to find information security, intellectual property and email policies; Information on how to enquire or make a related complaint. Where to find information security, intellectual property, and email policies.  
Data protection (how UCL uses student information)  
UCL uses student information for a range of purposes, including the provision of teaching and learning, managing accommodation and ensuring health and safety. Further information about how UCL uses student information can be found in the UCL General Student Privacy Notice.  
Students may send queries on data protection matters to the University Data Protection Officer (data-protection@ucl.ac.uk.)  
Information Security Policy | UCL  
Email Usage Policy | UCL  
Data Protection Policy | UCL  
Understand your intellectual property (IP) rights | UCL Innovation & Enterprise  
Report a Breach of Personal Data | UCL  
Storing and securing data  
Students are strongly encouraged to save their work on UCL's file stores, which are backed-up regularly. Storage space is finite, however students can request additional storage space from the Technical Support Group, for example where they are required to produce assets with significant file size.  
If students save work to their own devices, they should ensure their files are appropriately backed up to protect against data loss (which is not usually acceptable grounds for Extenuating Circumstances.) The UCL Dropbox service may be used to securely exchange files that may be too large for email or other services.

The service is free, independent, impartial and confidential. No information shared with the service is shared with the students department or any other university staff unless the student requests it or gives their permission. Students can complete the online contact form for advice and support.  
Student complaints  
Information on informal and formal student complaints.  
UCL aims to ensure that every student is satisfied with their experience of UCL. However, we recognise that from time-to-time problems do arise and students may wish to express concern or dissatisfaction with aspects of UCL or the quality of services provided.  
Before raising a complaint, Computer Science encourages students to ensure they have fully explored all options and avenues for discussion available to them.  
Whilst students do not need to strictly follow the route of escalation indicated below, many issues, and the need to escalate, can be avoided by speaking to the right people in the first instance.  
Informal resolution  
Many complaints can be resolved at an informal or local level without needing to submit a formal complaint. Students can speak to their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental or Faculty Tutor, Course Representative, or Research Student Representative if they have any concerns about their programme. They can also speak to the Students' Union's Advice Service. UCL strongly encourages this kind of resolution and does expect students to have attempted some form of informal resolution before making a formal complaint.

Equity, Diversity & Inclusion | UCL Computer Science  
UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours  
Information about UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours.  
Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse  
Every student and member of staff has a right to work and study without experiencing harm. Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse of one member of our community by another or others is never ok. UCL is working to eradicate these issues and seeks to promotes an environment in which they are known to be unacceptable and where individuals have the confidence to raise concerns in the knowledge that they will be dealt with appropriately and fairly.  
To help with this, UCL has Report and Support, an on-line reporting tool where students can report any issues anonymously or with contact details request to speak to an advisor in order to make an informed decision about their options.  
Examples of unacceptable behaviour include, but are not limited to: - Intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive behaviour which has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity or creating an intimidating environment. - Unwanted conduct related to a protected characteristic that has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity. The unwanted conduct can be physical, verbal, or non-verbal. - Unacceptable behaviour of a sexual nature such as sexual harassment, invitations, comments, coercion and promised advancement in exchange for sexual access.
reference: UCL's Information Security Policy advises students to safeguard their data by using UCL's file stores, which are regularly backed up, and by ensuring that any sensitive data stored or exchanged is appropriately encrypted with secure backup of encryption keys. Students are encouraged to save their work on UCL's file stores or use the UCL Dropbox service for securely exchanging large files. If students save work on their own devices, they should back up files properly to avoid data loss. For any data protection queries, students can contact the University Data Protection Officer at data-protection@ucl.ac.uk. Regarding complaints, UCL recommends that students attempt informal resolution before submitting a formal complaint. This includes speaking to their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental or Faculty Tutor, Course Representative, Research Student Representative, or the Students' Union's Advice Service. UCL strongly encourages resolving issues locally and expects students to have tried informal resolution to address concerns about their programme or data protection matters before escalating to a formal complaint.

user_input: How do Student Quality Reviewers contribute to the Student Partnership Committee's efforts to improve the student experience at UCL, and what role does student feedback play in this process?
response:
Student Quality Reviewers provide detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective on various areas of education. They can act as members of an Internal Quality Review panel or take on roles to review new programs or support enhancements to assessments (Source: Chapter 9, Section 7). Their insights help improve the student experience by providing evidence-based recommendations that staff consider when making decisions about teaching and learning.

Student feedback is crucial in this process. It helps UCL understand students' needs and experiences, which informs policy changes and improvements. For example, recent feedback has led to actions such as opening the Library over Christmas and increasing study space (Source: Chapter 9, Section 6). Student surveys are a key part of gathering this feedback, including Module Evaluative Questionnaires at the end of each term (Source: Chapter 18, Section 18).

By participating in these committees and providing feedback, students like Quality Reviewers help shape UCL's educational offerings to better meet student needs.
retrieved_contexts:
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.  
Student Quality Reviewers, where UCL students take an in-depth look at different areas of education and provide detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective.  
Through the Student Quality Reviewer scheme, students can: - Act as a member of an Internal Quality Review panel; - Take on a role to review new programmes or support enhancements to assessments through the Programme or Assessment Design Student Partner roles; - Work with staff to reflect on their teaching through the ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue scheme; - Provide a student view on how teaching can include more diverse perspectives as a Student Curriculum Partner; - Students are paid a stipend of £300 for around 25 hours work.

Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back  
Other ways (specific to the department/ programme) that students can give feedback, including local processes and key contacts.  
Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Elections  
Academic Representatives are appointed during early October. If a student takes up a representative role, the Students' Union will work closely with them to provide training, support, and advice, and they'll be able to change the experience of everyone on their course or in their department for the better. Even if a student doesn't want to take up a role, they should keep an eye out for a chance to vote for which students they feel will do the best job.

Departmental Student Partnership Committee  
Information on the role of the Departmental Student Partnership Committee.  
Every department at UCL has a Student Partnership Committee (SPC) that meets at least three times a year. Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. Most commonly, departments operate both an undergraduate and postgraduate SPC.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Chapter 9, Section 6.4: Staff Student Consultative Committees | UCL Academic Manual

Student voice - other ways to feed back

Student feedback  
The role of student feedback  
The importance of feedback and how UCL uses the results.  
Our goal is to put students' feedback, insights and contributions at the heart of decision-making. We value students' feedback and work with students as partners in the process of shaping education at UCL. In recent years, as a direct result of student feedback, we have opened the Library over the Christmas closure period and increased study space - including 1000 in the 24-hour new Student Centre, we've focussed more on environmental sustainability and given clearer information about exams and assessments.  
The framework of committees, processes, and activities through which students can provide feedback includes: - The student representative scheme, where the student body elects representatives across its programmes to act as the student voice (see Section 17 Student representation and voice | CS Student Handbook.  
Other opportunities for students to feed back on their experience include active dialogue with their module leaders via Moodle discussion forums, posting ideas or issues of concerns to their departmental student voice platform, or attending office hours with module leaders, programme directors, or with the Departmental Tutor.  
You Shape UCL | UCL  
Survey News and Results | UCL

reference: Student Quality Reviewers at UCL play a significant role by providing detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective on various areas of education. They participate as members of Internal Quality Review panels, review new programmes, support enhancements to assessments, and collaborate with staff to reflect on teaching quality and curriculum diversity. Their contributions align with the Student Partnership Committees (SPCs), which are co-chaired by Lead Department Representatives and meet at least three times a year to develop solutions to student concerns and prioritize improvements. Student feedback, gathered through multiple channels including surveys, module dialogues, and the student representative scheme, is central to this process. It ensures that students' insights and contributions are at the heart of decision-making, enabling SPCs and Quality Reviewers to work together effectively to enhance the student experience at UCL.

user_input: How does the role of the Student Representative at UCL support student and staff entrepreneurs in enhancing the student experience within the Department of Computer Science?
response:
- Start by understanding that Academic Representatives (ARs) are students' representatives who work closely with departmental staff to improve the learning environment. They proactively seek out students' thoughts and opinions on their programme.
- Steps:
  1. Keep an eye out for opportunities to vote for ARs during early October elections.
  2. Engage in Department Partnership Committees (DPC) meetings, which are co-chaired by Lead Department Representatives and where ARs work with staff to develop solutions to students' concerns.
  3. Use the Student Intranet platform to connect with ongoing discussions and feedback from peers on enhancing student experiences.
  4. Regularly communicate with your Teaching and Learning Administrator for advice and support, as they can help you navigate various issues within the department.
  5. Stay informed about Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term to provide feedback on learning experiences.

Source: Chapter 9, Section 6: Student Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual

Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. Most commonly, departments operate both an undergraduate and postgraduate SPC.

Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.  
We are very excited to have you with us this year and we're looking forward to supporting you through your time with us. user_input: How do the policies on summative assessments at UCL define the structure and feedback timelines for these assessments, and what specific provisions does the Computer Science department have regarding feedback and provisional marks?
response:
The UCL policy states that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. For Computer Science, this is 20 working days for taught modules and 10 working days for research project/dissertation modules (excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Provisional marks are released alongside feedback for coursework; for examinations, provisional marks will not be released as they take place close to the point of confirmed results. Feedback on exams is typically provided in a cohort-level summary rather than individualized details.

For Computer Science specifically:
- Feedback is expected within 20 working days after assessment submission.
- Provisional marks are usually released alongside feedback for coursework, and may precede it for examinations.
- Final marks are confirmed by the Board of Examiners and released via Student Registry Services.
- Students should contact their Module Leader or relevant staff with any queries about marking or expectations.

Source: Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Students are encouraged to contact the responsible examiner with any queries relating to how work will be marked or what is expected, either in class, via the Moodle discussion forum, or during Office Hours. In the event that assessment information is missing, incomplete, or unclear, students should contact the relevant examiner or Module leader, which should be via the module's Moodle discussion forum.  
Chapter 4, Section 2: Assessment Information | UCL Academic Manual  
Chapter 4, Section 4: Marking & Moderation | UCL Academic Manual  
Marking scales  
Computer Science operates a Numeric Marking Scale on its taught programmes of study, which means that each module is awarded a numerical mark (on a scale of 0.00 - 100.00) based on students' performance in that module's summative components of assessment.  
Some components are binary marked, which means that a genuine attempt will be awarded a mark of 100.00, otherwise the work will be given mark of 0.00. The aim of these assessments is to help students to learn but to relieve the pressure of chasing every mark.  
Some components may be designated as 'pass/ fail', which means that these do not attract a numerical mark but, instead, are given a binary pass/ fail grade. Such components do not contribute to the module's overall mark but, where used, are usually required to pass the module.  
Chapter 4, Section 3.7: Marking Scale | UCL Academic Manual

reference: At UCL, summative assessments are designed to evaluate students' achievement of a module's learning outcomes and contribute to their academic outcome. Each module has one or more summative components, each with a defined method, title, and weight, collectively known as the module's assessment pattern. Feedback on summative assessments is a key part of the learning process. UCL policy mandates that all students receive feedback within one calendar month of the submission deadline, which may include provisional marks, written feedback, discussions, or model answers. If delays occur, students are informed, and the extra time should not exceed one week. Specifically, the Computer Science department aims to release feedback within 20 working days of the assessment deadline, excluding weekends and holidays. Feedback may be withheld until approved extensions are completed to ensure fairness. For research projects or dissertations, draft feedback is provided within 10 working days if the draft is submitted at least 15 working days before the final deadline. The department monitors feedback return and notifies students of any delays via Moodle. Regarding provisional marks, Computer Science usually releases them alongside coursework feedback, but provisional marks are not released for examinations due to their proximity to final result publication. Final marks are confirmed and released via Student Registry Services after Board of Examiners approval.

user_input: How does the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme support first-year students, and what benefits can Computer Science alumni access as part of the UCL alumni community?
response:
The Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme supports first-year students by providing small-group programming assistance from more advanced Year 2-4 students. This helps beginners to improve their proficiency in languages like C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, while also allowing more experienced students to enhance their skills.

Steps:
1. Contact your assigned Programming Tutor for weekly support.
2. Attend the Meet Your Mentor session during the first week of term to meet your Transition Mentor.
3. Check the UCL careers website for alumni resources and networking opportunities.
4. Consider joining optional internships or placements through the department's career services.
5. Use myUCLCareers to access internship and graduate job vacancies.

Source: Programming Tutoring Scheme
retrieved_contexts:
All Year 1 undergraduate students will be assigned a Programming Tutor at the start of the academic year as part of the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme.  
The scheme is a student-led initiative wherein undergraduate students in Years 2-4 can apply to act as Programming Tutors to provide small-group support to students in Year 1 of their undergraduate studies. The scheme supports beginner programmers towards proficiency in languages such as C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and enables more advanced programmers to hone their skills. The scheme is coordinated by Senior Programming Tutors, who are responsible for recruiting and assigning Programming Tutors and for liaising with the department's staff.

Tutors will not be available every week, since all staff are required to take leave on occasion and will have competing demands on their time. However, staff will communicate their availability to their tutees.

user_input: What roles do Academic Coordinators play in managing taught programmes, and how do these roles intersect with the department's procedures for investigating and penalising academic misconduct?
response:
The Academic Coordinator plays a crucial role in managing taught programmes by overseeing student progress, ensuring compliance with regulations, and facilitating support services. They are responsible for:

1. Contacting students who have not submitted their work on time or have failed to attend classes.
2. Submitting evidence of academic misconduct to the SORA (Student Records Office) if necessary.

Warnings/Caveats:
- Ensure all actions comply with UCL's procedures and guidelines.
- Evidence is required when submitting cases for investigation.
Source: Section 3.3 - Staff Roles and Responsibilities

External Examiner  
Each programme has an External Examiner who works with UCL's academic staff to ensure academic standards, consistency of practice, and fair treatment of students. The primary responsibilities of the External Examiner are to review summative assessment methods, to review a representative sample of summative marked work, and to submit an annual report, based upon their professional judgement, about the programme. The External Examiner will consider: whether the academic standards set for the programme qualifications are appropriate; the extent to which the assessment processes are rigorous, ensure equity of treatment for students and have been fairly conducted within UCL's regulations and guidance; the standards of student performance in the programme, or parts of programmes; and identify comparable practice.

reference: Academic Coordinators have distinct responsibilities depending on the level of study. The Academic Coordinator for Taught Postgraduate Programmes oversees the delivery, review, and development of postgraduate programmes, including reviewing student feedback, leading programme reviews, rationalising modules, ensuring coordination between programmes, and supporting the Departmental Tutor with postgraduate matters. Academic Coordinators for Undergraduate Programmes manage teaching and learning within a designated year of study, acting as academic leads for teaching staff, ensuring quality and coherence of teaching, coordinating coursework deadlines to avoid clustering, providing timely information and advice to students, and managing tutorial activities. These roles are crucial in maintaining academic standards and supporting students throughout their studies. Regarding academic misconduct, the department has clear regulations defining misconduct, such as unauthorized use or sharing of code, and a zero-tolerance approach to contract cheating. Investigations into suspected misconduct involve examiners reviewing originality and integrity of submitted work, potentially using tools like Turnitin or Measure of Software Similarity, and may include oral examinations or panels. Penalties for confirmed misconduct can range up to exclusion from UCL or rescindment of qualifications. Academic Coordinators, by overseeing programme delivery and student experience, play a key role in ensuring students are informed about academic integrity policies and in supporting the enforcement of these procedures within their programmes.

UCL's Student Support Framework  
Details of how UCL and the department will support students through their studies.  
About the UCL Student Support Framework  
UCL is committed to providing the support students need in order to make the most out of their studies. The Student Support Framework draws together our main academic support processes under one banner to help students understand the options open to them.  
UCL's Student Support Framework  
The Framework includes the following components:  
Part 1: How to Use this Framework  
Helps students find their way around the different support options open to them. It includes: - Where to find help and advice - Information about when to use this framework (for example if you are an affiliate, study abroad or placement student) - Advice on confidentiality and how UCL will look after student data - Information on providing supporting evidence - Links to other support options that are available to students.  
Part 2: Types of Support explains how each of the following processes works:

Academic advice on specific modules  
For advice about a specific module, for example relating to its syllabus, learning outcomes, prerequisite conditions, or self-assessment of suitability, students should contact the Module Leader or general contact, whose contact details are set out in the UCL Module Catalogue.  
Administrative advice and troubleshooting  
If a student experiences any issues with making or confirming their module selections, they should contact their Programme Administrator.
reference: Academic references at UCL are personal statements usually provided by a Personal Tutor or Project Supervisor that detail a student's confirmed module results, provisional or conferred awards, and a summary of their achievements within their cohort. These references support applications for jobs or further study and should be requested well in advance, as they are typically only possible once results have been confirmed by the responsible Board of Examiners and may take several weeks to prepare, especially during busy periods. To assist students throughout their academic journey, the Teaching and Learning Team offers extensive support, including a dedicated member who can advise on various issues and connect students with appropriate resources. Students also have access to the Computer Science Student Intranet for news and events, and can engage with Student Representatives who present cohort views and collaborate with staff to enhance the student experience. The team is accessible via email, online drop-in sessions, or face-to-face appointments, ensuring students receive guidance and support when requesting academic references and navigating their studies at UCL.

user_input: What is the Computer Science feedback policy regarding the timeframe for releasing feedback on summative assessments, and how can students use the Computer Science X channel and Teaching and Learning Team drop-in sessions to address any concerns about delayed feedback?
response:
The Computer Science feedback policy states that for taught modules, feedback should be provided within 20 working days of the assessment submission deadline. For research project/dissertation modules, feedback is given on a draft version within 10 working days.

Students can use the Computer Science X channel and Teaching and Learning Team drop-in sessions to address concerns about delayed feedback:
- Use the Computer Science X social media channel for general inquiries.
- Attend Teaching and Learning Team virtual drop-in sessions during term time (Wednesdays at 10am, Thursdays at 11am) via Teams. These are quicker than email for resolving queries.

Source: Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back  
Other ways (specific to the department/ programme) that students can give feedback, including local processes and key contacts.  
Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Social media  
Computer Science is active on the following social media channels: - Computer Science X – the department's official X channel. - Computer Science YouTube –the department's YouTube channel. - Computer Science LinkedIn – the department's LinkedIn page.  
UCL Code of Conduct for Students | UCL Academic Manual  
How to stay safe when networking online | UCL Students  
Fraud and scams - Staying safe online | UCL Students  
Teaching and Learning Team Drop-in Sessions  
The Teaching and Learning team run a virtual drop-in session for student queries. The session runs in Teams. Although you do not need an appointment, you may need to wait if another student is already in the session. We encourage use of the drop-in, as it is often a quicker way of resolving a query than over email.  
Schedule  
Term-time, Wednesday 10am to 11am (UK time) ( This session is for MEng Robotics & Artificial Intelligence students only)  
Term-time, Thursday 11am to 12pm (UK time)  
You can join the drop-in using one of the buttons below. Please ensure you join the session appropriate to your programme of study.  
We operate a lobby-based queue system. You will remain in the queue until a member of the Teaching and Learning team is free to talk. When your conversation has concluded, we will ask you to exit the meeting so we can invite the next student in.  
Please have your Student ID ready when you join the drop-in. This helps us be more efficient in responding to your enquiry.  
You will only be able to speak to a staff member via the below links when the meetings are live.  
Important:  
There will be no Thursday drop-ins on 13 February, 20 March, and 10 April.  
Personal Tutor Office Hours

user_input: How do the UCL ChangeMakers scheme and UCL Careers services complement each other in supporting students and alumni at UCL?
response:
UCL ChangeMakers and UCL Careers services complement each other by providing different but supportive pathways for students and alumni. UCL ChangeMakers helps students and staff work together to improve education at UCL through collaborative projects funded by the scheme. On the other hand, UCL Careers supports students in their professional development and career planning after graduation or during their studies.

Steps:
1. Explore UCL ChangeMakers opportunities for funding and collaboration.
2. Apply for a project that aligns with your interests or needs.
3. Engage with Student Partnership Committees to identify areas needing improvement.
4. Consider the stipend offered by successful projects, which recognizes student contributions.
5. For career support, visit UCL Careers website for resources and events.

Source: Chapter 9, Section 7
retrieved_contexts: longer-term difficulties and UCL's normal mechanisms (e.g. Reasonable Adjustments, Extenuating Circumstances, Interruption of Study) are not providing enough support. We will work with you to put together a Support Plan to help you get the most out of your studies.

Information on module feedback, including when they occur and why they are important.  
Throughout all modules students will be asked to answer short pulse survey questions, on a regular basis.  
These pulse surveys are important because it helps teaching staff 'check-in' with students, making sure that they can understand and access key aspects such as the content of the module, assessment information and learning resources. This provides an opportunity for students to reflect on their learning and also give constructive feedback by engaging in a dialogue with staff about the results. Helpful comments and ideas from students mean that changes and improvements can be made to the module before it ends, as well as shaping the module for future students.  
UCL Changemakers  
Information on the UCL ChangeMakers scheme and how students can get involved.  
UCL ChangeMakers helps students and staff work in partnership to make education better at UCL: - Students and staff can apply for funding to collaborate on a project focused on enhancing education and students' experience at UCL. - Projects address issues that are important to students, often uncovered through student survey data, discussed at Student Partnership Committees, raised through Unitu or as the result of ideas from students and/or staff. - Students are recognised for their contribution to enhancing education at UCL through the payment of a stipend. - There are two application deadlines a year, in terms 1 and 2.  
Projects are open to all students: undergraduate, postgraduate taught and postgraduate research (MRes).  
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.

Volunteering Services  
Information about the Students' Union UCL Volunteering Services and how to become involved.  
About Volunteering Services, who they are and how a student can find out more or become involved  
The Volunteering Service at Students' Union UCL exists to connect UCL students with London's Voluntary and Community Sector, primarily through volunteering. It's one of the largest volunteering teams in UK Higher Education, meaning that UCL students have access to opportunities that their peers in other universities often do not.  
The Service runs three main programmes: - Partnerships linking students with volunteering opportunities within their network of around 350 community partners. - Student-led Projects supporting students to set up and run their own community projects. - Community Research Initiative connecting master's students with community organisations for collaborative research and Knowledge Exchange projects that form their dissertations.  
Through community volunteering, students develop new skills and learn how to enact change in the wider world. UCL Student volunteers also report positive benefits on their academic study and well-being.  
The Volunteering Service's opportunities can be found on its online directory, where students can search for roles related to their academic studies, by skills developed or by cause. There are plenty of one-off and flexible vacancies that students can fit around their studies and other commitments.
reference: The UCL ChangeMakers scheme supports students by enabling them to collaborate with staff on projects aimed at enhancing education and the student experience at UCL. Students can apply for funding, work on issues important to them, and receive a stipend for their contributions. This scheme is open to all students, including undergraduates and postgraduates. On the other hand, UCL Careers services are available to both current students and alumni for up to three years after graduation, providing career support and professional development opportunities. Together, these initiatives complement each other by offering students practical involvement in improving education through ChangeMakers while also providing career guidance and lifelong learning resources through UCL Careers services, thereby supporting students and alumni throughout their academic and professional journeys.

user_input: How can an international student at UCL utilize the Student Enquiries Centre and the Student Representative to address visa-related concerns and improve their overall student experience?
response:
To address visa-related concerns and improve your overall student experience at UCL, follow these steps:

1. Contact the International Office or Student Enquiries Centre for immigration and visas issues.
2. Engage with Academic Representatives to voice your thoughts on how to better support international students like you.
3. Attend Departmental Student Partnership Committee meetings to discuss visa-related challenges and propose solutions.
4. Submit an application under the Short-term Illness and Extenuating Circumstances procedure if extenuating circumstances prevent you from attending assessments or submitting work by deadlines.

Warning: Ensure all applications and feedback are submitted in a timely manner, as there may be strict deadlines for these procedures.

Information on the role of the Departmental Student Partnership Committee.  
Every department at UCL has a Student Partnership Committee (SPC) that meets at least three times a year. Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. [Extenuating Circumstances and Reasonable Adjustments | CS Student Handbook](

Academic Representatives  
Academic Representatives are students' representatives in student matters; they are members of UCL standing committees, including the Staff Student Consultative Committee, contribute to the Annual Student Experience Review exercise, and coordinate activity within the CS student hub, the department's student voice and feedback platform. Academic Representatives will proactively seek out students' thoughts and opinions on their programme of study and their wider learning experience; present students' concerns and feedback to the department; communicate with students on an ongoing basis about their work with the department, and any positive changes made as a result; play an active role in the development and enhancement of their programme; and promote the value of students and staff working together to build a better education.  
Further information: - Chapter 9, Section 6.3: Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual - Course Representatives | Students' Union UCL  
Admissions Tutor  
The Admissions Tutor is a member of the programme team who responsible for coordinating the process of admissions within a programme or programmes. This includes: setting admission targets and entry standards, monitoring student performance against entry standards, and confirming decisions to UCL Admissions. They act as the channel of communication with the Faculty Tutor and with the Head of Outreach and Admissions (Registry and Academic Services).  
Further information: - Chapter 12, Section 11: Responsibilities of the Admissions Tutor | UCL Academic Manual

reference: An international student at UCL can utilize the Student Enquiries Centre (SEC) as a primary resource for visa-related concerns by visiting their physical location on the 1st floor of the Student Centre for walk-in enquiries or by contacting them via telephone at +44 (0)20 3108 8836 during specified hours. The SEC provides guidance and information on a range of areas including Visa, Fees, Study Abroad, Student Support and Wellbeing, and other matters related to studies at UCL. Additionally, students can access support online through the askUCL self-help service, which aims to respond within five working days. Beyond the SEC, the Student Representative plays a crucial role in enhancing the student experience by acting as a liaison between the student cohort and the department. They present the views of their peers and collaborate with staff to improve the academic and social environment. International students are encouraged to engage with their Student Representative to voice concerns, including those related to visas, and to participate in shaping their educational journey at UCL. Together, the SEC and Student Representatives provide complementary support channels that help international students navigate administrative processes and contribute to a fulfilling university experience.

user_input: How do the Student Partnership Committee and the Student Enquiries Centre work together to support UCL students in addressing academic and administrative concerns?
response:
The Student Partnership Committee (SPC) and the Student Enquiries Centre collaborate to address academic and administrative concerns. The SPC meets at least three times a year with Academic Reps and staff to develop solutions for student issues and prioritize improvements. The Student Enquiries Centre provides a platform for students to report longer-term difficulties or access support, including reporting behaviours like harassment or bullying. Both entities work together to ensure students receive the necessary assistance and feedback mechanisms are in place. 

1. **Attend SPC meetings**: Stay informed about departmental student concerns and solutions.
2. **Report issues through Student Enquiries Centre**: Use this service for longer-term difficulties or support needs, including reporting harassment or bullying.
3. **Contact advisors at Student Support and Wellbeing**: For confidential advice on various issues affecting students.

**Source: Chapter 9, Section 6: Student Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual**

Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

longer-term difficulties and UCL's normal mechanisms (e.g. Reasonable Adjustments, Extenuating Circumstances, Interruption of Study) are not providing enough support. We will work with you to put together a Support Plan to help you get the most out of your studies.

If a student experiences any of these behaviours, they can report it and/ or access support. Students can request to be contacted by an advisor or they can report anonymously. With either option students can give as much or as little detail as they wish. The reports are strictly confidential and only shared on a need to know basis.  
Students can request to speak to all the following advisors: - Dignity Advisor - Crime Prevention and Personal Safety Advisor - Human Resources Business Manager (if it’s about a member of staff) - Student Casework Team - Independent Sexual Violence Advisors - Student Support and Wellbeing  
The department is committed to ensuring its staff and students are treated with dignity, and we strongly encourage students to report any instances of harassment or bullying they witness or experience.  
Support for students who have been affected by sexual violence and/ or domestic abuse  
UCL will do its utmost to support anyone who has been, or is being, affected by sexual violence and/or domestic abuse. If a student would like to talk to somebody at UCL, the Student Support and Wellbeing Team can offer advice on the support available both internally and externally.
reference: The Student Partnership Committee (SPC) at UCL is a departmental body where Academic Representatives and staff collaborate to develop solutions to students' concerns and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs meet at least three times a year and are co-chaired by Lead Department Representatives, who liaise between students and staff to enhance the academic experience. Meanwhile, the Student Enquiries Centre (SEC) provides a physical and online service to assist students with a wide range of enquiries, including those related to student records, fees, visas, study abroad, and Student Support and Wellbeing. The SEC offers walk-in, telephone, and online support during specified hours, helping students navigate administrative and wellbeing issues. Together, the SPC addresses academic feedback and improvements through student representation and committee meetings, while the SEC offers direct, accessible support for administrative and wellbeing concerns, ensuring that students have multiple avenues to raise and resolve both academic and non-academic issues during their time at UCL.

user_input: How do UCL Careers services support both current students and recent graduates, and what specific benefits related to careers and employability are available to UCL alumni through the UCL Careers platform?
response:
UCL Careers supports both current students and recent graduates by providing a wide variety of resources including one-to-one guidance, events, and access to recruitment fairs. They assist with exploring options, searching for vacancies, preparing CVs and applications, practicing for interviews, aptitude tests or assessment centres, and accessing internship and graduate job opportunities.

For UCL alumni, the platform offers exclusive benefits such as access to thousands of e-journals, use of the library, a UCL-branded email for life, and continued support through UCL Careers services for up to three years. Alumni can also stay connected through reunions, international networks, and interest-based groups.

Source: UCL Careers

Computer Science Careers Tutor: Tigmanshu Bhatnagar  
UCL careers  
Information on UCL’s careers services for current students and recent graduates.  
UCL Careers provides a wide variety of careers information, one-to-one guidance and events for UCL students and recent graduates. UCL Careers assists them through the entire job hunting process, including exploring options, searching for vacancies, preparing CVs and applications, practicing for interviews, aptitude tests or assessment centres, and providing access to recruitment fairs and other employment-related events. They can also advise on exploring options for further study and funding. Services and events are available to all taught students, researchers (PhD students and postdocs) and graduates (for up to three years after course completion).  
UCL Careers also supports employability activities within departments such as work-related learning and internships.  
UCL students are helped with applications and sourcing opportunities with web resources and advice. They can book appointments and search for internship and graduate job vacancies via myUCLCareers.

Information about the Students' Union UCL Volunteering Services and how to become involved.  
About Volunteering Services, who they are and how a student can find out more or become involved  
The Volunteering Service at Students' Union UCL exists to connect UCL students with London's Voluntary and Community Sector, primarily through volunteering. It's one of the largest volunteering teams in UK Higher Education, meaning that UCL students have access to opportunities that their peers in other universities often do not.  
The Service runs three main programmes: - Partnerships linking students with volunteering opportunities within their network of around 350 community partners. - Student-led Projects supporting students to set up and run their own community projects. - Community Research Initiative connecting master's students with community organisations for collaborative research and Knowledge Exchange projects that form their dissertations.  
Through community volunteering, students develop new skills and learn how to enact change in the wider world. UCL Student volunteers also report positive benefits on their academic study and well-being.  
The Volunteering Service's opportunities can be found on its online directory, where students can search for roles related to their academic studies, by skills developed or by cause. There are plenty of one-off and flexible vacancies that students can fit around their studies and other commitments.

This comprehensive support helps alumni stay connected and enhances their employability and career development.

user_input: How does the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme support first-year undergraduate students, and what role does the Head of Department emphasize in preparing students for technological advances?
response:
The Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme supports first-year undergraduate students by providing small-group programming support from more advanced Year 2-4 students. This helps beginners to develop proficiency in languages like C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, while also allowing more experienced students to enhance their skills.

Steps:
1. Contact the Head of Department for guidance on preparing for technological advances.
2. Register as a first-year student at UCL to be assigned a Programming Tutor.
3. Communicate with your Programming Tutor about weekly availability and support needs.
4. Attend Meet Your Mentor sessions during the first week of term to meet your Transition Mentor.

Warning: Ensure you have evidence of registration and are aware of deadlines for registering as a first-year student.

Source: Chapter 4, Section 11.8: Assistant Internal Examiners
retrieved_contexts:
All Year 1 undergraduate students will be assigned a Programming Tutor at the start of the academic year as part of the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme.  
The scheme is a student-led initiative wherein undergraduate students in Years 2-4 can apply to act as Programming Tutors to provide small-group support to students in Year 1 of their undergraduate studies. The scheme supports beginner programmers towards proficiency in languages such as C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and enables more advanced programmers to hone their skills. The scheme is coordinated by Senior Programming Tutors, who are responsible for recruiting and assigning Programming Tutors and for liaising with the department's staff.

Tutors will not be available every week, since all staff are required to take leave on occasion and will have competing demands on their time. However, staff will communicate their availability to their tutees.

Most modules have one or more coursework-based assessment tasks. The task instructions, marking criteria, and assessment deadline will be published via the module's Moodle page at the point the assessment is set. If a student is having difficulties understanding any aspect of the coursework, they should consult the member of staff who was responsible for setting it in the first instance. Ideally, and by default, coursework queries should be posted to the module's Moodle discussion forum so that all students benefit from any discussion. Module Leaders may set their own expectations for how issues should be raised.  
Coursework scheduling  
Coursework is scheduled by the module's teaching department. For Computer Science modules, coursework will usually take place as follows: - Term 1 modules: Weeks 6 - 20 (inclusive.) - Term 2 modules: Weeks 21 - 32 (inclusive.)  
Unless otherwise stated, the deadline time is 4:00pm (UK time) for submitted work, including if an extension has been granted via the Extenuating Circumstances Procedure. Coursework deadlines are published on each module's Moodle page in the assessment section.  
Coursework submission  
Procedures for coursework submission are set by each module's teaching department. For Computer Science modules, students must submit coursework digitally unless otherwise stated. The examiner may prescribe a particular file format, naming convention, protocol for group work, or composition for the submission, to which students should adhere.

# Method (or type) Title Weight (%) 1 Coursework Coursework 1 15 2 Coursework Coursework 2 25 3 Open book examination Online remote examination 60  
Each module's intended assessment pattern is detailed in the UCL Module Catalogue. In some cases, the actual assessment pattern may differ from the intended pattern indicated in the catalogue; this occurs where a late change to the module's assessments has been approved, after the publication of the catalogue. Where such changes are made, the Module leader will notify students on the module at the start of teaching. For Computer Science modules, the final assessment pattern will be indicated in the module's Moodle page, under the 'Assessment' section.  
Students who need to undertake a reassessment in the late summer assessment period may be set reassessments of alternative methods to the original tasks; this occurs where the original method is not feasible in the late summer assessment period. If a student needs to take reassessments, they will be notified of the details before the reassessment period.

To support students through these assessments, the Computer Science Student Intranet provides a live space for news, events, and departmental updates, evolving with student input via Student Representatives. This integrated support framework ensures students have access to timely information and assistance throughout their assessment periods.

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.
reference: The Department of Computer Science at UCL offers a portfolio of taught programmes designed to engage students and equip them with skills to address global challenges. These programmes have evolved alongside the department's growth and reflect contemporary computer science. Modules are delivered across the academic year, with assessments typically including coursework such as online or class tests, oral exams, presentations, and practical assessments. For Computer Science modules, coursework assessments are usually submitted during the term in which the module is delivered, plus an additional two to three weeks. Term 1 modules are assessed from Week 6 to Week 20, and Term 2 modules from Week 21 to Week 32. Examinations for these modules take place between 29 April and 30 May 2025. The academic year is divided into three terms: Term 1 runs from 23 September 2024 to 13 December 2024, Term 2 from 13 January 2025 to 28 March 2025, and Term 3 from 28 April 2025 to 13 June 2025. Reading weeks occur during the weeks beginning 4 November 2024 and 17 February 2025. The department carefully manages assessment dates to consider students' workloads, and deadlines are not set during closure periods, weekends, or UK bank holidays. Final year projects and dissertations have assessment periods to be confirmed. This structure ensures that teaching programmes and module assessments are well integrated with the academic calendar and provide clear timelines for students.

user_input: How do the Student Partnership Committee and Student Quality Reviewers schemes at UCL complement each other in enhancing the student educational experience?
response:
The Student Partnership Committee (SPC) and Student Quality Reviewers (SQR) schemes at UCL complement each other by providing diverse perspectives on education. SQR members offer detailed feedback from a student perspective, while SPCs involve students in developing solutions to their concerns with staff. This collaboration ensures that both the academic experience and administrative processes are continuously improved based on student input.

Steps:
1. Attend SPC meetings to provide your insights and vote for representatives.
2. Apply for UCL ChangeMakers projects if you have ideas or issues to address.
3. Serve as a Student Quality Reviewer to review new programs, assessments, or teaching methods.
4. Engage with staff through Office Hours to raise concerns or suggestions.
5. Participate in Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) to provide feedback on your modules.

Caveats:
- SQR members are paid £300 for their work.
- SPC meetings occur at least three times a year, and you can vote for representatives during elections held early October.
- Office Hours sessions run regularly but may not be available every week.
retrieved_contexts:
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.  
Student Quality Reviewers, where UCL students take an in-depth look at different areas of education and provide detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective.  
Through the Student Quality Reviewer scheme, students can: - Act as a member of an Internal Quality Review panel; - Take on a role to review new programmes or support enhancements to assessments through the Programme or Assessment Design Student Partner roles; - Work with staff to reflect on their teaching through the ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue scheme; - Provide a student view on how teaching can include more diverse perspectives as a Student Curriculum Partner; - Students are paid a stipend of £300 for around 25 hours work.

Elections  
Academic Representatives are appointed during early October. If a student takes up a representative role, the Students' Union will work closely with them to provide training, support, and advice, and they'll be able to change the experience of everyone on their course or in their department for the better. Even if a student doesn't want to take up a role, they should keep an eye out for a chance to vote for which students they feel will do the best job.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Academic Representatives | Students' Union UCL  
Find your representative | Students' Union UCL  
Chapter 9, Section 6: Student Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual  
Departmental Student Partnership Committee  
Information on the role of the Departmental Student Partnership Committee.  
Every department at UCL has a Student Partnership Committee (SPC) that meets at least three times a year. Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. Most commonly, departments operate both an undergraduate and postgraduate SPC.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Chapter 9, Section 6.4: Staff Student Consultative Committees | UCL Academic Manual
